definition:
An abelian group $D$ is said to be divisible if for any $x\in D$,
$n\in{{\mathbb}{Z}}^+$, there exists an element $x'\in D$ such that
$nx'=x$.

Some noteworthy facts:

-   An abelian group is (as a ${{\mathbb}{Z}}$-module) if and only if it
    is divisible.

-   Every group is isomorphic to a subgroup of a divisible group.

-   Any divisible abelian group is isomorphic to the direct sum of its
    torsion subgroup and $n$ copies of the group of rationals (for some
    cardinal number $n$).
